direction.raw_text: Something is rising from the Black Hills. A sphere of light, too red to be the sun. A sphere of contained fire, undulating in crimson and ochre, and rising slowly, majestically, to the pulse. To the DRUM. It is the sun. But it is a Paha Sapa sunrise. A Black Hills sunrise. And it is spectacular. The DRUM, pounds deeper, bigger, as the sun gets higher. Stronger. Igniting a vast landscape of gentle slopes and foothills; throwing shadows on the plains that look like, as the Indians say, an old man dancing. The grass is golden. And high. The wind moves through it, snakes through it. Slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Voices; a TRADITIONAL INDIAN SONG (Lakota), summoning Wakan Tanka - The Great Mystery. And now, rising up over one of the small land waves, a head comes into view. Shoulders. A man, running in ghostly SLOW MOTION, his long black hair trailing in the wind. The INDIAN MAN wears only buckskin pants and a bone choker around his neck. Legs and arms churning, the man runs with antelope grace, backlit by the sunrise, bounding toward us. Running... his heart pounding. SONG RISING... DRUM POUNDING... FIVE MORE VOICES in high-pitched tremolo join the song. And then the runner soars, like an eagle from a bluff, airborne, flying over a small dip, arms outstretched, and it would be a wondrous thing if there were not a fine, crimson, mist all around him and if slow motion was not suddenly overtaken by LIVE SPEED, revealing the brutal force of gunfire which has slammed the Indian into the air, throwing him. Slamming him hard into the grass. And it is over as quickly and violently as a deer shot dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ends abruptly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the sun burns like lava at the horizon. DRUM beats like a heart. And Somewhere off in a distant cottonwood, an OWL. Then Silence. Deep, disturbing stillness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . D.C - DAY ROCK N'ROLL shatters the silence. Cars -- a multicolored metallic criss-cross reflecting off a building made of mirrors -- races past an electronic billboard that blinks in red skyhigh digital: PRUDENTIAL LIFE INSURANCE. 7:59. 73 degrees. The D.C. Superhighway. And off behind it, in the distance, Capital Hill holds imposing vigil, the massive cast iron dome of The Capital, catching the sun. But everything is soon smothered by a METRO BUS, hogging the far lane of the Beltway, leaning on its HORN. Good morning. And the rock n'roll is everybody's radio, everybody's tempo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shimmers across the beltway hugging then releasing a solitary vehicle that we stay with... move with... A black Nissan 240 SX, hard-waxed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the wheel -- an intense young man with close-cropped black hair, eyes hidden by sunglasses. Whatever he does for a living, he does in a suit (not expensive but well-fit. But we might also note that any extra suit cash has gone instead into the silver-plated watch on his left wrist). Lean as a rake, sallow in the cheeks, there is something insatiable about him -- a hungry energy that won't let him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: late 20's, early 30's, pulls out of a threatening traffic jam and races on the narrow right between thirty cars and a cement girder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The black SX has jumped off an exit and has entered the light- industrial section of Washington. It pulls up near a loading dock behind an old gray building and several parked cars and vans. Ray steps out, smooths his jacket, locks and SETS HIS CAR ALARM. Another young man -- chubby, clean-shaven; in a nicer suit than Ray's -- steps out from a parked Miata, and approaches Ray. CARL PODJWICK balances a coffee, a U.S.A. Today and a black eel-skin briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start walking briskly toward the loading dock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They mount steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop at the door of a service elevator and Carl breathes. Expanding his chest, exhaling. Ray adjusts Carl's tie for him, his collar. He speaks quietly. Quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carl nods. Ray hesitates, adjusts his own collar and enters the service elevator. Carl follows. Door closes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. Nice tie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get too attached.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya got the paper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're my hero, Carl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heroes ain't supposed to shake. I'm shakin', man, look at me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Breathe, Carl. Four, nice, deep ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone stops us going in, we're with the Bowen-Hamilton Textile Company. We have rug samples.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rug samples.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are one-dimensional, boring peddlers of fine carpet, Carl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carl follows Ray into the big sparse room of unfinished sheetrock walls. There is nothing in here but cardboard boxes, and two people; a bearded HISPANIC MAN standing behind a counter, writing on a clipboard. The other is a middle-aged BLACK MAN in a purple silk shirt sitting in a chair with a newspaper held open. He barely looks over the top of the Wall Street Journal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray walks up to the counter. Carl lingers, fidgeting. Ray sets his briefcase on the counter and click-clicks it open. The Hispanic fence man looks inside, and begins pulling out stacks of treasury checks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gestures to Carl and he nervously sets his briefcase on the counter, fumbles with the first latch. The second. He flips it open. The fence man casts his eyes down at a neat cache of Grade A Treasury. A lot of it. Then his eyes rise to Carl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fence man pushes an intercom button and yells into a speaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carl's eyes flit to Ray. Ray's eyes flit to Carl. Louis crushes his newspaper down and lifts a big Colt Python from his lap just as -- A section of sheetrock kicks open and THREE FEDERAL OFFICERS bust out, each clutching a handgun, SHOUTING inaudibly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carl startled, does an almost effeminate dip down to one knee, but that knee is swept out from under him, slapping him flat onto plywood where he is instantly frisked down by the fence man who is wielding a 9 mm handgun. But the white collar criminal is more stunned by the fact that -- Ray is walking across the floor with his hands in his pockets over to the Mr. Coffee. He pours one, and adds some milk. Turns and watches the bust while opening a packet of Sweet n'Low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray rests his weight against the coffee station, takes a careful sip. Carl is yanked to his feet by the fence man and he stands there, looking at Ray, baffled. Completely shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coffee in hand, Ray walks briskly toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns. Louis takes a few steps toward him, putting his gun back in his waistband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stands frozen, holding the door knob, and digesting what are apparently influential words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray just stares for a moment. Then hurries out the door. Carl, being arm-gripped by two agents and photographed like a trout, gazes bewildered at the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, look who's here.

dialogue.raw_text: Have the girl count it, we can't sit around here countin' bonds, we got things to do here.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't have one, Carl. I have a number, man. Just like the numbers on those treasury checks. You stole from your own country, Carl. Shame on you.

dialogue.raw_text: Make sure ya spell my name right.

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) We just spent four months together... I thought he was my friend... what the fuck, man? (even more incredulous) He had dinner at my mother's.

direction.raw_text: at him, an agent on either side, striking a natural pose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EDGAR HOOVER BUILDING - ESTABLISHING - DAY The huge, imposing, mausoleum-like Hoover building, bordered by artificial turf, hemmed by cherry trees in blossom. Turning out to be a nice day on Pennsylvania Avenue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 8x10 BLACK AND WHITE PHOTOS dealt like cards onto a table, one on top of another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: an aerial shot of some wasteland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a closer bird's eye of the same, what looks like a NASA photo of Mars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a vast expanse of the Great Plains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TULLY, Number-Two-in-Command, deals a fourth photo onto the table. He is an understated, fatherly man, well- manicured in cotton pencil-striped shirt, white-tab collar and tie. The photos and maps and files a foot deep on the huge table are neatly organized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seated, at the far end of the table, engrossed in the deep spread of information, SA (Special Agent) FRANK COUTURE is about to break the record for longest single ash on the end of a cigarette and the smoke forces his eyes into tight, concentrating, slits. "COOCH" as they call him in the Bureau has seen thirty years in some rough "provinces". He has survived the Hoover era and is a legend in the Sessions era but survival has honed an edge. An edge with a touch of ironic cop humor. Ray enters, walks into a firm shake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sits nervously across from Cooch who looks up from the photos and studies the younger man through reading glasses and cigarette smoke, and he looks at him like he doesn't know who the hell he is or why he's sitting there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch sticks his cigarette in his left hand, shakes with his right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The handshake is still locked. Cooch is still squinting at the younger agent. Ray obviously knows something about Agent Couture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tully leans back in his chair, crosses his legs casually.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray's enthusiasm suddenly deflates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks completely baffled now, swinging a look from Cooch to Tully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods, looks from Tully to Cooch. What's going on here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tully straightens the edges of a bureau memorandum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Ray lowers his eyes to the photos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks up at Cooch. Another uneasy beat. Cooch lights a cigarette as if lighting a cigarette was a science.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sits before the files and photos, looking unsure. He has come to garner a promotion but has just been sent to The Graveyard. Or in the FBI argot, Indian Country. Tully pivots his leather chair in a full circle and slaps an assignment folder down in front of the young agent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Levoi, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mister Tully.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No, no. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Levoi, Cooch. Raymond Levoi, Criminal Division.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah -- right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray this is -- RAY / TULLY Frank Couture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's an honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray, we're taking you off the street. We need you out in South Dakota.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: South Dakota... (confused) Did I do something unsatisfactory, Sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Ray. You're gonna have to blame that on your grandmother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Interesting bloodline you have, Ray. (scanning file) French, Scots-Irish, Italian, ...and one-eighth American Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sioux Indian, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not that sure. Yeah, I think -- TULLY -- yes, Teton Sioux. Father's side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray, there's been a homicide out in an area known as The Badlands. Indian Reservation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not the first. There's been several. And our field office in Rapid City is getting a lot of heat... none of the investigations have turned up jack shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The main problem is, Ray, these people are extremely distrustful of outsiders, non-Indians. Relations have not been amicable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Different culture. Hard to penetrate. The Indians don't like white cops poking around. And that's why we're in a position where we have to bring in an American Indian agent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With an Indian representative out there, we hope to keep hostilities dormant; this is a COINTELPRO, Selective Operations Unit, and it'll be easier on Agent Couture if you can gain the people's trust and maybe -- RAY Woh, excuse me, Sir... I see what you're saying... I've got a little Indian blood, that's true. But -- (laughing) I am not an... an Indian. I can't just go in and -- TULLY -- your father was part Sioux.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know him, Sir. He passed away when I was six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about it, Ray. As long as the people have proof that we sent them one of their own, no one's gonna ask you to weave baskets or make it rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The very landscape from opening image. Gentle waves of land, rolling out to touch the Black Hills. The sun rises up out of the distant silhouette like a waking God. HEARTBEAT DRUM. Hypnotic. And then a car blows by, throwing up gravel and agate and gypsum. ZOOOOM! Right by us. Gone. When a dense screen of red dust clears, an old, bent, metal sign at roadside becomes visible. It reads, through punched and rusted bullet holes: "Entering Bear Creek Indian Reservation."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: calls in the high-pitched, mournful voices of LAKOTA SINGERS. The same haunting song.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch is at the wheel. Ray, passenger. His lap is a desk for several folders, and he works through them as they drive. Both agents eat a sandwich as they travel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch opens a folder that sits between them, and taking his eyes off the road for a dangerous five seconds, locates some photos, and hands them to Ray. Ray's expression tells us they are not pretty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray considers this as he looks out at the unfamiliar terrain while on the RADIO, a D.J. speaks in LAKOTA LANGUAGE. Ray... back at Cooch, studying his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray smiles, sets the AC on high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch throws a quick look Ray's way. And a smile. He appreciates the sting of a right off a left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray has finished his sandwich. He wipes his hands on a kerchief while taking in the sight of chalky buttes cramming roadside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch looks at Ray, amused. He likes this guy. And then he notices a look of growing consternation on his partner's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eight murders in less than a year. All of them Indian. All of them unsolved. Is the law a non-entity out here or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those are two agents who went into a reservation a few years ago to serve a warrant. They were executed at close range. That one there is a police officer killed by the Mohawks up in Canada more recently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The agents who have worked out here say its like going into Nam. Unfamiliar terrain, foreign language, foreign customs... and you never know when you might walk into a few rounds. They hold a lot of old anger for the white man out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were you in Nam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Airborne. That's where they used to get us agents from. Now we get 'em from Carnegie-Melon, Ivy League. Accountants and computer whiz-kids. Yuppies with guns. (lights a smoke) That's scary shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not as scary as a Hoover man with a computer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, hey, hey. J. Edgar would've loved you. He'd love anybody who joined the bureau to, what was it? "To enforce the laws of my country and protect her interests"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You crashed my file?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I consulted it. We're going into Indian Country, I wanna know what kind of individual is covering my ass. Don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been in the bureau for thirty years. You survived The Hoov, the Black Panthers and Abscam. I don't see any bullet holes. That's good enough for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as they drive through the first settlement, a little, broken and scattered community, littered with wrecked cars on blocks, and overpopulated with hungry dogs. HEARTBEAT DRUM softly under.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with dirty but beautiful faces and long blue black hair run alongside the car, curious. One of them YELLS SOMETHING we don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the trading post -- a white man's store -- where SIX OGLALA SIOUX -- four men, two women sit like wax figures, only their eyes moving to light on the freshly waxed government car. A little house has a tipi erected beside it. And a satellite dish. The house beside that one has been half chopped away to feed the wood stove. Poverty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The federal car drives out of the community and further into vast bluffs and strange rock formations where it is swallowed, leaving the ramshackle village in dust. A lone dog -- all its ribs showing -- chases, BARKING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are on the Moon. Or Israel. But not America. Not any America we've ever seen. A thirty-mile eroded landscape of dunes and crevices, soft rock strata and fossils. Barren. And eerie. A LAKOTA DEATH SONG underscores the otherworldly ambiance of this place as -- SHOES scuff through the gumbo and multi-colored stones. Two pair of black, spit-shined, lace-ups. Three. Tripping. Scuffing. And then a fourth pair. But they are not loafers. They are Georgio Brutini's and they belong to -- Ray, as he and Cooch follow two Special Agents from the regional office. SA MILES is about Cooch's age, balding. SA SHERMAN is closer to Ray's age but instead of a suit like the rest, he favors an army-green jacket. Neither is a South Dakota shit-kicker but transplanted field agents. All four shield their eyes with dark glasses, and here in the Badlands it is wise because the sun makes dunes shimmy and craters become faces. It plays mischief on the eye, making Ray and Sherman nearly trip on -- A DEAD BODY lying face down in the rainbow sand. Dried blood and horse flies cover his blown out torso. The agents stand over him, breathless from the rugged walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch studies the body from where he stands. Sherman hands a file over to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The agents start back through the Badlands. Ray is already squatting a safe distance from the body, covering his nose with a kerchief while looking in the file. Cooch takes a bended knee on the other side of the body. Flies buzz on and around the corpse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch makes a note then slowly circles the body. He holds a hand out to Ray and the younger agent turns the file over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gets closer, swats at Flies with the folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks up impressed. Cooch rises and walks off gingerly, scanning the surroundings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch is standing ten feet away, staring at the ground. Ray walks over, carefully. He follows Cooch's frown down at the twisted layers of earth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who found him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indian kids. Hunting fossils.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. I think Agent Levoi and I can proceed from here. What are your call signals?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and 11. Anything we can do to help you out, just radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Thanks, Guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo Fast Elk... Thirty seven... single... Member of the Tribal Council.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like Fast Elk wasn't fast enough to outrun that load. What do you make of the damage?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Six rounds. 357.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what it looks like, doesn't it? But that's what a ten gauge, choke-bored, shotgun will look like when it hits your lower back from five feet away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody was serious about doing this guy, that's for sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a circle has been etched deep in the soft gumbo, and in the center of the circle, a white eagle plume sticks straight up, dancing in the wind. Cooch and Ray each lower themselves to their haunches to study the strange sight. Cooch puts his reading glasses on, stares at it. Then lights a cigarette. Ray hefts up a camera and begins CLICKING off shots. He starts moving around it, taking shots at different angles. And then the sound of a DISTANT MOTOR draws both agent's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : way out in the bizarre moonscape of eroded rock and earth, a lone figure on a motorcycle bounces and grinds, born out of a silvery heat mirage. It's fifty yards off but heading straight for us. The HEARTBEAT DRUM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RAY AND COOCH try to make the figure out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the archaic mud-caked Harley chugs and stalls, spits and choices, and begins an incredible drive straight up the steep side of this natural wonder. At the throttle is an imposing figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is a portly Indian in his late-thirties with a black reservation hat worn low over a face that seems to have been cast from a bust of Sitting Bull. Sitting Bull with aviator shades. Denim jacket over checkered shirt. Faded jeans. Well broken duct-taped boots. His hair is worn long in tight duel braids. The rusted bike bajas up and down slopes, finally stalling out, twenty feet or so from the murder site. Crow Horse swings his bulk off the bike like dismounting a horse. He looks around suspiciously then pulls a rolled-up blanket from the carrier rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lies in death. Crow Horse's boots move in stealthily, creaking like saddle leather. He squats and looks at the corpse... then looks around with animal alertness. He reaches into the front pocket of his jacket and pulls out some Bull Durham tobacco. He pinches some and offers it to the four directions around the body. He then unrolls the blanket, begins to move the dead man... sense something and wheels to see Cooch standing behind him, one hand behind his back where his gun must be, and the other hand holding up open wallet. The sun hits his badge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse hawks his eyes onto a big rock, a full second before Ray steps out, his .45 drawn but held at ease. Crow Horse slowly raises his arms as Ray moves up to him, studying him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray frisks the Indian, finds an old leather wallet, and then a gun. A .38.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch walks around to the front of Crow Horse, and studies him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pause. A long, dead of South Dakota, Badlands pause. Cooch turns and looks at Ray who holds up the open wallet, revealing a badge. Like Cooch's it shines in the sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch stands staring at the Indian... then takes a few steps over to Ray and grabs the wallet. He examines it. Then looks at Crow Horse and laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Indian cop has plenty of time to get up on his own but he kneels there, tauntingly, waiting for Ray to help him. Ray walks over and offers a hand. Crow Horse takes it, and pulls himself up, looking square into Ray's sunglasses. Cooch walks over and hands the officer his wallet, and his .23. Crow Horse takes the items, eyeing the older agent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray does a take but quickly recovers, meeting Crow Horse's scrutinizing gaze. Crow Horse nods to Ray, and Ray nods back in case it's the Indian thing to do. Crow Horse nods again. Ray nods again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stares at Crow Horse, uneasy. The wind sings through the Badlands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse says something in Sioux to Ray. Ray just stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse is staring at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks offended. Cooch puts a hand on Crow Horse's shoulder and walks him toward his beat-up motorcycle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse turns and looks at Ray. Ray is quick this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse appears to be getting on his bike when suddenly he moves like a cat and lays his knife to the dead man's head. He cuts away a patch of hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch and Ray stand there, watching Crow Horse mount his bike and push off down a nasty slope back through the Badlands. He starts his motor. It dies. Then starts again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Cooch look off across the Badlands, as far out of their element as they can be.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Taking ol' Leo somewhere?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo's been out here too long, man. I'm taking him to ceremonial burial.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a restricted area.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Check him out, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice piece. You come back here to cover your tracks, Geronimo? What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't Geronimo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think maybe you guys got off the wrong exit, yeah? This is the Bear Creek Indian Reservation.

dialogue.raw_text: I know where I am. I'm on federal land, doing a federal investigation, and if you don't wanna cooperate you can take a ride in a federal car, and spend the rest of the day in a little room, answering federal questions. It's your call. Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a full blood Oglala Sioux, born and raised on this reservation.

direction.raw_text: ON - THE WHITE EAGLE PLUME in the circle in the sand, fluttering in the wind. The gold spit-shined Le Baron eases to a crawl, passing an old wooden sign. "Leaving Bear Creak Indian Reservation." And immediately pulling in front of a squat old bar with a burned out neon Miller light. DWIGHT YOAKUM croons "Youuuuuu- Got-Your Little-Ways" on the jukebox from inside. The Buffalo Butte bar has several cracked and sun-bleached buffalo skulls hanging off the edge of its flat roof and big faded white letters painted across the front read: "No Indians Allowed." (This sign actually exists today in the res-line border town of Scenic, South Dakota). The car pulls up beside a pick-up and parks. Ray and Cooch step out, careful to walk wide around a PITBULL in the bed of the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: walks out of the bar and looks askance at the suits. As the two feds approach the bar, Cooch looks up at the warning sign. Ray sees it too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young agent smiles, amused, starts to enter the bar but -- VOICE (O.S.) Hey! Ray spins quickly, paranoid about entering. But the man calling to them is -- An Indian himself. TRIBAL PRESIDENT OLIVER CLEAR MOON, a small man in his late fifties who peers out at the agents through fat bifocals. He wears a straw cowboy hat, red windbreaker and his hair is cut short, or "bobtailed" as the Indians say. Clear Moon is walking away from a parked pick-up truck, toward the white men, eyeing the two with deep curiosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch discreetly peeks into a folder as he walks toward the man
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is pointing his long, skinny finger at Cooch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear Moon beholds the young agent with hopeful eyes, a smile breaking across his flaccid brown skin. He takes Ray's hand in a respectful double-clutch and grips him tightly... almost desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He keeps pumping Ray's hand, looking into his face with great admiration. Cooch looks on with amusement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear Moon has not released Ray's arm as he leads them to a string of seedy motel units across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Clear Moon guides them through the front door of room 13. Ray looks over his shoulder threateningly at Cooch who winks and pats his back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Ray. You're gonna have to wait in the car. I'll bring you out a cheeseburger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (heavy Indian accent) You made it. Was-te.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be... President Clear Bone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clear Moon. (pointing to the sky) Moon. You must be the Sioux.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. That's Ray here. Ray...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Ray Levoi, Sir. Pleasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's about time they sent us one of our own. Was-te.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things are no good here. It is like war zone. We need an official who understands what is good for the Indian people. Who knows Indian way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we were staying on the reservation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Rooms thirteen and fourteen are on Indian land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you hungry? I have some nice raw kidney in the truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm set, Sir. I'm set.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's starving, Mr. Clear Moon. Get him some raw kidney. He hasn't had any Indian food in days...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A lone headlight appears out of the black. HEARTBEAT DRUM. But faster. Relentless. A "res" car, a dented, rusted, peeling old station wagon, drives slowly toward the reservation. Then suddenly, someone steps in front of the car. A BIG MAN in cowboy boots and blue jeans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray lies in bed. Awake. He is hanging off the bed with a file open on the floor and using the moon to light photos and memorandums. And then he hears LAUGHTER outside. And GLASS BREAK. He gets out of bed quickly, snatching up his pants, putting their on, and going to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: out in front of the bar help a middle-aged INDIAN MAN out of the station wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young local bends down behind the Indian while another shoves him, sending him tripping over the bent man and onto his back in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where you goin'? Back to the res?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What ya doin'? You drunk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: come out from the bar, beers and drinks and interested in what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RAY at the window, observes. Cooch enters from the connecting room, puffy-eyed but quickly buttoning his shirt. He shares Ray's view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is transfixed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's take a walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Indian man, is pushed into a stumble, and caught by another white man as a little game of catch takes place. Cooch, stepping into the circle, shirt half unbuttoned, hair a mess, looks on. Then steps in front of a big local and catches the Indian as he comes stumbling. He holds onto him, looking at the faces that turn his way. Ray steps up beside him, looking tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then Cooch shoves the Indian with all his might back across the road. The locals resume their fun, and Cooch looks at a local man and shares a chattering laugh that makes Ray do a serious take.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Indian ends up stumbling back toward Ray, and Ray catches him this time. The man maintains a perfect vacant expression and keeps acting as though nothing of the sort is happening. But he is dizzy, and exhausted, and Ray keeps him from falling. Cooch looks at Ray. Their eyes meet. Ray shoves the man forward. This time, instead of catching him, the local on the receiving end, hauls off and punches him in the face. The Indian drops. Cooch runs in, grabs the Indian under the arms and drags him back to his car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shoves him behind the wheel as the locals crowd around. They don't see Cooch throw the wheel stick in drive, and lean into the man's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch slams the door, and kicks it, and the vehicle lurches forward. A beer can clanks off the rear window, and rolls clanking into the middle of the road. Ray stands there with the locals as they all watch the car drive off across the reservation line. Cooch, belly sticking out of his unbuttoned shirt, and a breathless smile on his face, heads to the bar without breaking stride. This man has done "underground" before.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's goin' on here? (a beat) I can't walk across the goddamn street without some breed-ass fallin' all over me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Watch out now, he wants a kiss, Ray, wants a kiss --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, skin, get your ass back on your sacred land. Get outta here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get outta here. Drive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SHORT TIME LATER Cooch and Ray sit in a booth with DENNIS VAUGHN, a strapping local man, ranch-raised, and gentlemanly. In fact, downright likeable.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So what type of salesmen are you gentlemen anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Liquor. We heard they like their drink on the reservation, and we were gonna see if we couldn't unload some surplus on the way to Nebraska.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now keep that between us, Dennis, cuz I don't know what kinda Johnny Law they got here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Brooks, come over here. I want you to meet a coupla fellas from Denver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a small, older man with a feed store cap and a clean cowboy shirt, comes over with a beer and a pensive look on his face. He pulls up a chair and positions himself at the end of the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch and Ray don't flinch. Dennis does. He looks between the two, cautiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch laughs good-naturedly. Ray smiles. But Brooks looks offended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray catches this. Glances a look off Cooch who works on a cold draught beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both men shake their heads. Get quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch shakes his head, distracted, and the two locals leave, enroute for the pool table. Ray watches them go, curious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Liquor salesmen. Be nice to them, maybe they'll give you a sample of some of that gin you like. (to Ray) He likes that Russian shit that -- BROOKS They ain't liquor salesmen. They're FBI.

dialogue.raw_text: Brooks, what's a perceptive fellow like you, doing in a joint like this? Let me buy you a glass of some of that Russian shit you like.

dialogue.raw_text: ? What you investigatin'?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Again. Figures, man.

dialogue.raw_text: You'll never find out who did it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You underestimate me, Brooks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. You underestimate these grass niggers. They're killing each other. That's all they do. Get drunk and kill each other. Then cover for each other. Who gives a damn really as long as they stay on their reservation. You ask me, the government shouldn't care one particle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how in your big cities, you got your niggers and you got your Puerto Ricans? Well out here we got Indians. That's just the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only good Indian is a dead Indian, does that old adage still hold true out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That set-to you saw out front, was nothin' more than a message we were sendin' to the sonsabitches that are divertin' water from the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got rights. We got a ranch just up here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did any of you gentlemen know Leo Fast Elk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fellas are here to investigate a Indian crime, you should keep to Indian land, and talk to them, not us. But you wanna drink here and shoot stick here, that's your right, and we respect that. (to Dennis) Come on, Son, we're up on the table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fellas wanna play doubles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray and Cooch, cross the street back to the motel. It is black and chillingly still.

direction.raw_text: Cooch looks at Ray, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop in front of their rooms and Cooch pulls a small tape recorder from his waistband. A micro-cassette recorder that he examines in the dim door light.

direction.raw_text: Cooch shuts it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Ray the recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch starts for his room but in a long, exaggerated country step as he breaks into the HANK WILLIAMS tune that has all but driven him insane inside the joint. Ray watches him go, and cracks a laugh.

direction.raw_text: Ray's at the wheel, looks intense as he studies the vast expanse of slopes and rock formations and the rising sphere of flame that lights the road in strange color. He is reading a name list that he traps against the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray pulls up a long dirt drive and parks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks- Dreamer. (a dry run) Hello, I'm looking for Hobert Standing- Buffalo-That-Walks... Dreamer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray walks to the front door of a war-torn trailer that is halfway swallowed by weeds and plants. It is static out here. Dead still. Ray approaches the front door. There is a huge hole in it. He knocks above the hole. After a moment, the door opens a crack. A dark, weather-beaten face barely shows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door closes. Locks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stands there for a moment then lowers himself to look through the huge hole in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tattered chair is pushed against the door, covering the hole. Ray stands up, turns on the steps. And before he can let out a flustered sigh, he spots something across the dirt road. Something that makes him remove his shades, look again. Whatever it is, it doesn't make him happy, and he is hurrying across the road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning. I'm looking for Hobert- Buffalo-Dreaming... (cheat sheet) Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --Dreamer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A motorcycle, parked between the road and the badlands. We've seen the ancient bike before. Ray walks past it, looking at it. He pushes his shades up on the bridge of his nose and looks down into the moonscape. Walter Crow Horse is down there, on his haunches, "feel tracking", laying his fingers inside tracks and reading them. He doesn't even look up at the sound of the FBI agent's footsteps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wind whistles and moans through the Badlands as Crow Horse continues feel tracking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray draws back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse lowers his face to the ground and blows some scattered dust out of a print. Lightly lays his fingers inside
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse checks out another track.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse rises, points down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is frowning at the big Indian, trying to get a fix on this
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse walks back up toward the road. Ray lets him leave then crouches where Crow Horse was, begins looking at tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns, and sees Crow Horse perched on a high bank -- the one Ray came down -- and he's in a tracking stance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray just stands frozen, blown away. Crow Horse rises, dusting off his hands, and heading to his vehicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Indian turns. The wind moans. Ray scrutinizes him, deliberating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse grins and waves, and ambles away. DOWN IN THE BADLANDS Ray stands, sweating under his suit jacket, and not sure if he's amazed or pissed off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ray Little Weasel. FBI. I like the way ya sneaked up on me. Must be Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you -- CROW HORSE Watch out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're steppin' on sign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. (ignored) Hey, you, listen up -- CROW HORSE -- Leo wasn't killed here. He was dumped here. Out of a vehicle. Bald tread. Muffler held on with baling wire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man you want... stepped outta the car, dragged Leo out, laid him down. Then walked over here and made a circle in the earth with a stick. I can't find the stick. He stuck an eagle plume in the circle, got back in his car, dustin' his own prints with a pine bough for about six feet, but he missed a print, right here, see. He got in his car and went Hell- bent-for-Holy-Sunday outta here. He ditched that pine bough three miles across the flat, in the Little Bear River, it floated down to Thundershield Gap. The car hit paved road, and was outta here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The killin' was done where Leo's mother lives. But he was driven here into these Badlands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Big sonuvabuck. Based on the depth of that print, pressure releases... I'd say he goes two-ten, two-fifteen -- RAY Bullshit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, maybe two-seventeen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're trying to tell me you can read all that from a track?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Not just a track. You gotta listen to the trees, man. To the leaves. To this sand, you FBI's kicked all up. You gotta listen to the earth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that right? Well, listen to this: drag your ass. This is a restricted area.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, this is the home of the Oglala Sioux and I want the dog-fucker who killed Leo. Whether you get him or I get him, I just want him. Shit's been goin' on too long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got no jurisdiction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got no know-how. About Indian Way. Or about Jack Shit for that matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you're not aware of this, Crow Horse, but I just flew in from a place called the Twentieth Century where we have such things as electrostatic tracking methods, psycholingusitics, DNA fingerprinting; I don't have to crawl around with the scorpions and talk to the fucking trees to get answers. Leo was killed right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go back to the M.E., take a look inside Leo's exit wounds and tell me how chicken feed got in there. Trust me, there ain't chickens in the Badlands. His mother's place is -- RAY -- his mother never lived here. She was from up in North Dakota.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talkin' his spiritual mother. Maisy Blue Legs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His spiritual mother...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To us Indians, our spiritual relatives are as close as family. I've got seven mothers on this reservation. Sisters. Brothers. You ain't one of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God. Now listen to me, asshole. I'm giving you a break. But if my partner finds out you're here, you're gonna be reading rat tracks in Sioux Falls Maximum Security.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy. Easy... I'm goin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hey, Little Weasel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weigh one sixty-three, yeah? Not a beer drinker. You're one of these tofu and pilaf characters. Pack your gun, under your coat -- left shoulder. But you got backup; a little .32, .38 maybe, in a ankle holster that gives you a right foot drag, Shoes are too tight at the toe but, man, they look cool. And that's what counts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crow Horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A trailer sits off from the river in beaten solitude. There are two junked cars and one burned black. Wind blows across deep bald tire tracks. Ray walks slowly beside them, surveying, following them to a place where they become puckers and skids next to a dilapidated outhouse. There is a shotgun blast in the side of it. Ray studies it, enters the outhouse. Exits, and walks the rutted gumbo earth to where it meets rolling hills of golden grass. He stands here, mesmerized.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT MAISY BLUE LEGS HOUSE BLACK TAIL DISTRICT

direction.raw_text: scratch around in the dirt. Like so many far-off res homesteads, this is a haunting place. Made more so by a persistent SQUEAKING, a rusty, metallic squeal coming from -- A WATER PUMP across the yard, where MAISY BLUE LEGS, a Sioux elder, works the handle. She wears thick bifocals and keeps her hair under a bandanna. No water comes forth from the pump, and she tries again and again until she breaks a sweat. And then she sees the waal'cu standing out there. Urgently, she turns and starts back to her trailer with an empty coffee can. Ray starts after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She mounts the metal steps. Ray is losing her. He gets a foot on the bottom step, and attempts something he does not want to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halfway through the screendoor, Maisy turns and looks at the young man in suit and shades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maisy lowers her bifocals, studies him. Then walks in, slaps the door shut, and locks it. A towel hung as a shade folds down. Ray lingers at the bottom of the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he walks around the side of the trailer, looking at the ground. In the gaping space between the trailer blocks, and the grass, there is much junk stored, and Ray kneels to look. He is drawn to a pair of cowboy boots, caked with dried mud. He picks up a boot, looks at the sole, then touches the mud. His fingers break through the hardened crust and come back moist and blue. He looks at this sniffs it. There is a tense, water-torture like tempo coming from the old pump where water barely drips onto a hub cap in the dirt. Ray sets the boot down. Goes to grab the other boot and -- a WESTERN DIAMOND BACK RATTLER coils out from the shade of the boot, RATTLING and HISSING from white mouth and three- inch fangs, and Ray has done a backflip and roll, slapping his shoulder holster and pulling lead and BLAM! BLAAAM! he unloads two, and the reptile is so dead, there's not even enough snake left to make a truck-stop key chain. He kneels there, flushed in the face, holding his breath and double-clutching his gun. The SHOTS ECHO through the Badlands like the aftermath of dynamite. From inside the trailer, he can hear CRYING. A low moaning. Praying softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then his RADIO CRACKS IN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks down at the dead snake, still rushed from it, and he hurries out of there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear Moon gestures for the little girl to run off. He leans in close to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clear Moon is looking past Ray at the Warriors. They are approaching the agents, and Clear Moon looks at Ray with great concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he slowly retreats to his lawn chair under the arbor. Chasing Hawk, Maggie and the other Warriors strut up to the agents. All but one who is bound to a wheelchair. We've seen RICHARD YELLOW BIRD, the big Cheyenne who wears a Red Power baseball cap, an earring, and thick bifocals -- in one of the file photos. His arms are plastered with tattoos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The warriors make a show of not acknowledging the FBI presence. They have walked over here just to walk by them. That is there statement. But Yellow Bird stops cranking the wheels of his chair and stop: long enough to look up at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even the agents crack grins at this bit of Indian wit. All but Ray who just stands there, arms folded across his chest, considering the crippled activist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird sits there, staring up at him through thick glasses But then Maggie Eagle Bear takes the handles of Yellow Bird's wheel chair. She looks at Ray with eyes that are choke- cherry black, eyes that look right through him. He returns the glare. And then she pushes Yellowbird forward and leaves the feds alone. Ray turns to Cooch who is lighting a cigarette, and concentrating on the movements of this group as they wander under the arbor, visiting people. LAKOTA SINGERS start up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Magedelana Eagle Bear. Eagle's claws and a bear's balls.

dialogue.raw_text: She keeps an AR-15 assault rifle in her truck. And she'll use it.

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Clear Moon.

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to kill me next. That's what I hear. These new Indians are destroying everything. Our people are a quiet people.

dialogue.raw_text: They can lead us to Jimmy. Just let them go. We're tightening the net on him. We know he's on the reservation.

dialogue.raw_text: Help us.

direction.raw_text: The front door creaks open, and the subject dashes back out. In the dark we cannot latch onto features. Suddenly the junker van comes alive, guns onto the dirt road, racing toward the running Indian who gets the door of the truck open but freezes in the van's highbeams as -- Ray leaps out, M-16 in hand.

direction.raw_text: Ray maneuvers in Quantico fashion, keeping the rifle on the Indian's back. The Indian drops what he's holding. And turns around. It's not a he. We've seen her before. At the Powwow. Maggie Eagle Bear. Her hair is pulled back tight, braided. Ray moves in toward her, surprised at first, but still cautious
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does what he tells her. As Ray moves in on her, he notices an INDIAN CHILD sitting in the passenger seat, looking out into the highbeams, frightened. Ray toes Maggie's legs out wider, frisks her one-handed, pats down her boots.

direction.raw_text: Maggie turns around, looks Ray in the eye. He looks self- conscious in the cowboy hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is looking down at what she dropped. A bundle lying in the grass. He bends down, starts to untie it.

dialogue.raw_text: freeze, Motherfucker -- drop it, drop it!

dialogue.raw_text: Turn around, put your hands on the roof of the truck.

dialogue.raw_text: You're the Indian FBI.

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Turn around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The people are glad they sent you. They usually send in guys who come at ya with highbeams, screamin' "drop it, Motherfucker", stick a gun in your face, frisk ya down. Even if ya got a child with ya. No, it's good to have ya. It's gonna be was-te times on the res.

dialogue.raw_text: I was gonna warn ya about messin' with somebody's medicine bundle but I forgot you know all about that stuff.

direction.raw_text: an eagle skull, tobacco strings, sage, sweet grass, and several white eagle feathers.

direction.raw_text: Ray doesn't have a clue as to what this radical bullshit is about.

direction.raw_text: If this information doesn't throw Ray, the use of his first name does.

direction.raw_text: Ray is holding the medicine bundle. He deliberates, then hands it over. She takes it with careful hands, casting a somewhat surprised look up at him.

direction.raw_text: Maggie gets in the truck, starts it up. She looks out at him, studying him. Trying to figure him out. HEADLIGHTS are coming fast from down the main road.

dialogue.raw_text: This Jimmy's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not gonna catch him. He can shape-shift into different animals. Bear. Elk. Porcupine.

dialogue.raw_text: Is that like an hereditary thing, Magdelana, or can one take classes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jimmy didn't kill Leo. Why do you wanna do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He tried to kill him twice before. That's a good place to start don't ya think? Leo was on the other side, wasn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo was an apple, that's right. Red on the outside, white on the inside. And Jimmy hated him. Kicked his ass a coupla times. But he didn't kill him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who did?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the FBI. That's your job, isn't it? Ya know how many of our Warrior brothers got killed out here? I never saw any investigating then. Why now? What's going down here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fugitive Alert for a murder suspect. Before somebody else gets a shotgun blast in the spine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try the Fort Laramie Treaty. All over again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look. You and I can stand here in a culture clash til the sun comes up, talking about what's right and what's wrong. You're from the reservation. It's a different world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm from Minneapolis. Fifth Street. I did four years at Dartmouth before I ever set foot on this res. So I know about the other world, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you gonna keep that medicine bundle or are you gonna respect its power?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you see Jimmy, tell him the sooner he turns himself back into a human being and gives himself in... the sooner we back off this reservation. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grandpa Reaches says you come from heavy Indian blood. I used to think Grandpa was gettin' senile. Now I know he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move it, Magdelana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Miles and Sherman's vehicle pull in behind it. The regional feds fall in behind Cooch, everyone, packing rifles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns, nodding. An FBI van pulls in from the other direction and FOUR AGENTS empty out, wearing FBI windbreakers and heavily-armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch nods. The agents form a tight unit out below the upside down flag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray reaches inside his pant leg, down around his boot and carefully removes a white eagle feather. He gingerly tucks it in a plastic bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sherman and Miles, take off. Cooch, an impressive master of COINTELPRO, now turns to the van squad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The van squad moves toward the house, leaving Cooch and Ray alone in the highbeams that light the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods, impressed. Cooch bends down near the road, touches the dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch wipes the oil on a handkerchief as he rises, smiling playfully at Ray. He starts back toward his car. Some sort of bird is COOING in the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks up at the upside down flag. Then watches Cooch walking way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch, standing there with his glasses on and his right arm bandaged, looks tired, too. He gets in his car. In the yard, Ray starts for the van, the res dog, trying to follow. He chases it away. And then as he gets closer to the van, he looks up to investigate the COOING SOUND.

dialogue.raw_text: Ray, you alright?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She talks a lot of shit. We're not doing our job. Jimmy's innocent. "What's the FBI really doing here." Some shit about the Fort Laramie Treaty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She took something from the house. What she called a medicine bundle. Most likely Jimmy's.

dialogue.raw_text: Let's see it.

dialogue.raw_text: I gave it back to her.

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it is Jimmy's, she's taking it to him. We'll have a runner. But I borrowed a little mojo...

dialogue.raw_text: Way to go, Raymond. Miles, take that to lab. Sherman, I want you to go back to base and produce some written material. Something that indicates that our girl Maggie is leaking information to us. And make sure that material finds its way into the hands of the Warrior Movement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gentlemen missed that medicine basket. Go back through the house, and make sure you missed nothing else. And lay some wire, too. Let's do it.

dialogue.raw_text: That's good goddamn work, Ray. Let the salmon run. Let 'em run Upriver.

dialogue.raw_text: Why we setting Eagle Bear up as an informant?

dialogue.raw_text: Her own people start to suspect her, it creates discord from within. The Warriors don't know who to trust, they start infighting, and Jimmy loses his support.

dialogue.raw_text: Her oil pan is shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cooch. What's the Fort Laramie Treaty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, I don't know. You tell me. You're the Indian.

dialogue.raw_text: Get a tail on her, Ray.

dialogue.raw_text: Cooch. (a quiet, tired laugh) Where the fuck did they send us?

dialogue.raw_text: A long way from home. You be careful out there.

result.heading: AT THE TOP OF THE FLAG POLE

direction.raw_text: Ray looks up at the pole, watching. Then walking on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mind-blowing sunrise of airbrush red. Clusters of lodge-pole pine. The spectacular mesa. PAINT HORSES graze in a field, a few out in the center of the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the old man comes down the front steps in a frail walk, carrying a paper plate. He steps down into the sage clusters that grow just off his trailer, and offers the plate up toward the sky. He then stoops, and scrapes a half-eaten English muffin, some potato chips and half a banana onto the Earth in a neat pile. He straightens his back the best he can, looks up again, and prays softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: possess an otherworldly beauty at this magic hour, a maze of shadows and rainbows. In the distance we cannot mistake the frame of Walter Crow Horse. He's out there, long hair blowing against the white bluffs. Stalking. Tracking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a puppy chases a hen in a klutzy, innocent manner then bumps into the tire of a parked car. Taking a shot at doghood, he hikes his leg, squirts a hubcap belonging to -- Cooch's Le Baron. Cooch leans on the hood, drinking a coffee from a foam-plastic cup, and supervising SIX G-MEN who have a map spread out over the hood and are discussing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is way out in a remote corner of the res, a little home, trailer and tipi right on the river. The river is rushing hard this morning, catching the light of the sun. Maggie's truck is parked in front. Out at the river, Maggie, her hair long and unbrushed, and wearing an extra large T-shirt and nothing else is hauling water in buckets from the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: are with her, helping her. Near the house, an OLD WOMAN in bifocal glasses, feeds some chickens, and a cat that gathers with the chickens and eats feed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray, still in his field clothes sits, training binoculars on the distant house. He opens a carton of milk, drinks some. Then hears a whimpering. In the passenger seat sits the three legged res dog. Ray has taken him with him. He drinks some milk, then opens the carton up fully and sticks it out so the dog can lap it up. Ray laughs in disbelief, shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dog is lapping the milk, desperately. And then a ROARING. A motorcycle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For all I know, you're Jimmy. And you're just waiting for a shot at my jugular. Drink, Jimmy. Milk is good for you --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Crow Horse, racing up on the left of the van. Ray pulls his hat down low, and sits back. The motorcycle passes on the left, slowing enough so that Crow Horse can flip Ray the middle finger. Then he races on, far down the road. Ray sits there, shaking his head. He'll let it go. Bullshit. He starts the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse guns in, sliding in dirt up to the run-down, low budget shooting range -- six plastic milk jugs on sticks, jammed in the mud. A moment later, the van hammers in. Parks. Ray gets out. He's removed his hat so as not to invite any crap from Crow Horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray executes a hard, slapping, "up your ass" gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse bursts into laughter in his raspy, staccato laugh. He walks off a few steps, picks up a spent shell and pitches it. His laughter simmers and he gets serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse fingers an eagle feather that hangs from his hat band.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse stares, a little surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray absorbs this with great interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray lets a pent-up sigh escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse chews this over, unable to hide a nagging frustration. He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two of them stand there, thinking this over. Ray takes out his notebook and starts writing. Crow Horse walks away, turns to face the propped up targets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To punctuate, Crow Horse slaps leather, draws his .38, and begins blasting at the milk bottles. He hits the bank. A tree. One of the posts. But not a single target. When he is done, he looks over his gun, disappointed. Starts reloading. Ray starts laughing, looking at the missed targets
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, sees that he's serious, and follows him toward his motorcycle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse turns toward Ray, and creates a long dramatic pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he hauls his bulk onto his motorbike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse winks at Ray as he slams the kickstart. To no avail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Crow Horse nails his kick start. The BIKE ROARS alive and the Indian works the throttle hard, leaving gravel and black exhaust. Ray stands there, drifting between logic and instinct. He looks at his watch, then starts at a slow, thoughtful shuffle toward his car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be mad. That was just an old traditional gesture that means hello, how are you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. Forgive my cultural ignorance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a nice day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jimmy didn't do it, Ray. I checked it out. You can stop taggin' my sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's your sister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spiritual sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gotchya. We just nailed a genetic match between the eagle feather left at the murder site and one in Jimmy's medicine bundle. It came from a white eagle. Same bird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So did this one. Wambli is a rare and sacred creature. When someone finds a dead one, the feathers get around the res. We share everything. A lot of power in the eagle feathers. But you think that's bullshit too, don't -- RAY (ala Crow Horse)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo Fast Elk was sitting in the outhouse at Maisy Blue Legs when a car pulled into the yard. He came out, approached the vehicle then saw that the man behind the wheel was Jimmy. He tried to get back into the trailer, but the car came highballing at him. He started running for the open grass. With the car moving, Jimmy hung his shotgun out the window, took aim -- missed once, hitting the shitter -- fired again, and severed Leo's spine. Leo fell, rolled, and came to a stop in the grass. And some chicken feed. Stale chicken feed with four days mold. (a beat) Electromagnetic printing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was-te. 'Cept for one thing. Jimmy Looks Twice was nowhere near there. Ya see, when Jimmy was twelve years old, his mother and father was killed in a car wreck right down there near Elk Mountain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see the connection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The connection is, it did a head number on him. He's petrified of cars. Won't drive. I've known him all my life, and he's never gotten behind the wheel of a vehicle. He rides passenger and he rides horses, and that's it. The man that shot Leo down was behind the wheel of a moving car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not solid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want solid? That one, single, print he left in the Badlands -- the one the FBI missed and then stepped all over -- it belongs to a man who walks heels first. Like a white man. Jimmy has a serious Ind'n walk -- ball of the foot first. The man who murdered Leo walked like a Wasi'cu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're saying a white guy did it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When Leo was dumped out there in the Badlands, he was dropped on his back. Our man made an effort to turn him over, onto his face. It's an old Ind'n belief that if a dead man is turned face down, his spirit won't leave. And in the killer's case, it won't come back and jump all over his shit. That's an Ind'n thing a white man wouldn't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's the way it is. Write it down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You laugh all you want, Breed. Sunset tonight, I get my man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, Crow Horse. I'm listening. I'm listening to the trees, to the stones. Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damned if I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the Old One. He did a Yuwipi ceremony last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The old man? He's gonna tell you who killed Leo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go catch Jimmy, Ray. Really. He's gettin' away. Go ahead, go get him. I'm late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey. Hey, those are my sunglasses you're wearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grandpa traded with me. (flips the bird) Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The dust-buzzard broncs and bounces down Grandpa's driveway, coming to a stop near the wrecked cars. Crow Horse dismounts and unhooks a carton of smokes from the back. A moment later, the junker van pulls in, bouncing and shaking. Crow Horse stares at the approaching vehicle, his eyes hidden behind Ray's former shades. He cracks a slow smile because -- Ray is stepping quickly from the van, and carrying two packs of Marlboros.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa sits in his chair, his black eyes moving smoothly from side to side. Smoke enshrouds his ancient face, giving the sense of another time and place. He speaks LAKOTA. Crow Horse, sitting on a stool across from him, holds The Pipe. He passes it to Ray who sits in a busted lawn chair next to him. The room is dark as the sun sets out the window in red and purple. Ray looks at the pipe. Grandpa will not speak until Ray smokes. And so he does, drawing on the stem, awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Grandpa speaks Indian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, searching for a hint of lightness. But there is only great reverence as he watches Ray blow smoke upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray smirks as he passes the pipe to Grandpa. Crow Horse looks nervous. Grandpa offers the pipe to the directions and then disengages the bowl from the stem. He speaks again. Crow Horse translates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa leans closer to Crow Horse and whispers some Lakota.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Grandpa is already holding out something to offer. It is a cigarette. Grandpa offers it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse tells the Old Man. Grandpa speaks Indian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray buries his hands in his jacket pocket. No way. Crow Horse signs to Grandpa "no." Grandpa gets up, crosses between the two young men, up to the TV set. He turns it on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He says, back behind Red Deer Table, where the Elk-People-used-to-live... there are strange creatures from another world who eat stones... and who will kill anyone who crosses into this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says, in the Yuwipi ceremony last night, he saw you... going back into the land beyond Red Deer Table. I was with you. But that was all the Spirits let him see so he doesn't know if you were killed or not. But he thinks you probably were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to the land where the Elk-People- used-to-live and you will find the answers you came here looking for. But you must go as two. That is the vision. I have spoken. And this is so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to trade. (a beat) He likes your watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do that, (explaining) It's a Rolex.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, this is -- (loud to Grandpa)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: this is very, very expensive. It's -- (to Crow Horse) Tell him this is an expensive watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says, you need to go on Indian time. He says your watch is ruining your life anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: explodes in PINGS AND PONGS and a WOMAN'S SHRILL SCREAM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse and Ray walk down the steps. WHEEL OF FORTUNE is heard from within.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They step into the yard and Ray stops, turning to Crow Horse
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse drives "Indian" home with a hard finger in Ray's chest. Ray knocks his hand away, explosively. Crow Horse is ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man is standing at the top of the steps. Ray and Crow Horse are YELLING OVER EACH OTHER, and hands are up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stands there, one hand up in defense, another poised to throw a punch. Bewildered, he stares at the old Indian holding onto the porch railing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Grandpa goes back in, screendoor slapping shut behind him. Ray is just staring, his jaw dropped. Crow Horse starts laughing. Harder than he has yet, and Ray starts walking toward his car in fuck-this steps. He gets into the car, closes the door and looks out the open window at Crow Horse. The Indian moves first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray lifts his arm off the door, and springs his middle finger up at Crow Horse. He holds it there for a long moment just looking at the big Indian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray checks the time on his watch then guns away. Crow Horse stands there, watching him go. Eventually he shuffles back toward the trailer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Red Deer Table, Ray.
