dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me: heavy duty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heavy, heavy duty. Taku Wakan. Wanagi Spirits. It's one of those few places we'd never go to as kids. Still don't. Some of the old people say Crazy Horse is buried back there. We have to go Ray. Together. Like his vision.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Walter. When I fill out my 302, do I say that evil spirits are killing everybody on the reservation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray -- RAY -- no. No offense to the old man. I appreciate you trying to help. But I put my ass on the line coming out here, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you expect to hear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not Native American myths and legends. I'm with the FBI, Walter, remember? Not National Geographic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you call myths, we call our history.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not real.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's real to you? Wall Street? Capital Hill? Now they are myths.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't be dicking around here. That's all I'm saying. I don't carry crystals, I don't wanna come back in another life. I just wanna do my job, and do it right, and get the fuck outta here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't no Indian. You're a Sal Mineo Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Knock it off!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will ya knock it off? You're actin' like a couple of old women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For cryin' out loud. Knock it off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He speaks English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only when he's really pissed off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come inside. Watch TV.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't accuse nothin' of not bein' real, Little Weasel. Cuz the only thing around here that ain't real is you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care of yourself, Walter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Likewise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Room 14 has been transformed into a major COINTELPRO base; four computer terminals are set up, card tables spread with photos, boxes of files stacked on the bed, and SIX AGENTS, manning the computers, thumbing through files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A meeting takes place around a table of paperwork and coffee cups, and a .45 laid atop a file. Cooch, SA Miles, SA Sherman, TWO OTHER REGIONAL AGENTS and Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch taps some ashes into an empty coffee cup. They sizzle in cold residue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The agents all look at Ray. A pin can be heard falling to the cheap carpet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch nods, lights another smoke, intrigued.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've gotten word that Jimmy has been trying to hook up with Maggie Eagle Bear... but some of the Warriors have been sending word to Jimmy that she may be an FBI operative. So he doesn't know where to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bingo. It's working.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's out of room. All the reservation exits have been watchdogged. We got him. I give it twelve hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well we better use those twelve hours to apprehend the right man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The right man? Talk to me, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoever dusted Leo, dusted him from the driver's seat of a moving car then drove those eight miles to the Badlands. Jimmy Looks Twice has never been behind the wheel of a car. It's a known fact out here that he's petrified of driving. His parents were killed in a car wreck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not very solid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was also a print found in the Badlands that indicated diagetic locomotion. Heels first. Jimmy's walking pattern doesn't match. He has a distinct Indian walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indian walk? You been smoking hooch in the peace pipe, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Except for Cooch who just stares at Ray, digesting what he has said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sherman looks at Cooch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch nods to Ray and Ray follows, gathering up some paperwork He looks determined as a terrier.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They don't smoke hooch in The Pipe, Miles. They smoke something called kinickinick, it's like a tobacco.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're right about X21 being a Washington Redskin, that's for sure. What else, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You boys want a soda?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah, a Coke. You buying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Ray's buying. Sherman? Coke?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... no. No, Cooch, I'm working on a coffee here. Indian walk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray and Cooch throw long, slim shadows on their way to an archaic Coke machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray studies him with a smile building. Cooch shrugs, sips some soda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods, starting for the van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns. Cooch looks at him for a time. It is a warm look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gets in and pulls the dog out. The dog sits at roadside, tilting its head at him, confused. And he pulls out. It runs after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Genetic ditto on evidence found at the site with evidence you found in his belongings. An incontrovertible motive. And definite footprints on Jimmy Looks Twice at Maisy Blue Legs house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When did we get that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today. And now you -- there's a dog in the van -- RAY -- I know. I fed it, and I can't get rid of -- COOCH You weren't sent here to go off on your own detail, Ray. You were sent here to assist in a Selective Operations Unit. These regional agents are inept -- that's why they were sent out here to The Graveyard, to Indian Country. I need you behind me, Ray. Not pulling against me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not trying to pull against you, Cooch. I've just been having nightmares about the way Leo was killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your first homicide, that's gonna happen, Ray...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanna make sure no one else gets done in that way because we were in bed with the wrong doer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray. I never get into bed with somebody unless I know for sure. Just the way I was raised.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright. Alright...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lightly) Yeah, alright, alright -- fuck you -- give a yuppie a badge and he wants to take over the world. Go get a tail on Eagle Bear, and stay with her. Cuz Jimmy's gonna show. And I want you to make the collar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll sleep around a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Cooch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And get rid of the dog.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The van sits parked down the road from Maggie's dimly-lit home. Ray sits behind the wheel, watching the house. LOCUSTS make a steady and unnerving sound. It is black. Black under big sky. Ray lets his head sag out the open window and he takes in the vastness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : stars. Millions of stars. And an incredible full moon. It hangs huge over distant fields, a perfect sphere. The top half of the moon is yellow, the bottom half a lava red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RAY stares at it, lost in thought. From Maggie's house, he hears someone SINGING. Singing a traditional SUNDANCE SONG while they haul water from the creek. A WOMAN'S VOICE, trilling out the beautiful but haunting "hey-o-hey-o-hey-o-hey-ohhhhh." Ray just sits, listening. And then something draws his attention to his rearview mirror. The res dog, lying in the back seat is GROWLING. Lip curled back, growling low. Ray looks at him, looks out the window. Blackness. Nothing but the sound of locusts. And a slight crosswind in the wheat fields. The dog stops growling. And Ray fixes his gaze on the house again, lifting a pair of binoculars and -- BOOOOOOM! The rear windshield is SHATTERED by an explosion. Ray throws himself low across the passenger seat -- BOOOOOM! The driver's side window and part of the door explodes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The federal van is HAMMERED BY GUNFIRE. All the windows, shattered, the metal doors splayed. Someone is going for the kill,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is thrown open just as its window implodes, and Ray slides out belly first, gripping his M-16 and crawling like a dog soldier into tall wheat at roadside as the car, the road, the wheat, the dirt, the night are slammed by gunfire. The res dog overtakes Ray and vanishes in the wheat. Ray vanishes, too. It is quiet for a moment, then Ray, pops up ten feet away, and UNLOADS THE M-16, in a left to right, clean sweep before dropping again. He lies there, listening. The LOCUST HAVE GONE QUIET. His breath is heavy. His heart's got to be pounding through the dirt he lays in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Motherfucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the decimated van, aerial still high. The distant lights of Maggie's house. And the giant Moon, hovering over it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: into -- SAME ROAD  RES - DAWN TWENTY FEDS comb the dirt road, the wheat fields, picking up shells with gloved hands, scanning the vast distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of Maggie's, FOUR INDIAN CHILDREN stand with the Old Woman, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch, flushed in the face, mans the wheel. He wears only a T-shirt which indicates, a desperate rush to the scene. His eyes scan the surrounding homes and fields. In the passenger seat, Ray sits, drinking a coffee. He looks haggard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns around in his seat, looking off across dry land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does. Ray is turned around in his seat, staring off into the distance.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: LE BARON TRAVELING ANOTHER DIRT ROAD

dialogue.raw_text: Bastards...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I could think of was... not here. I don't wanna eat it on an Indian Reservation, three thousand miles from home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's out there. He's out there playing Sitting Bull with us. I want the motherfucker so bad I'm getting a bleeding ulcer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It may have been Maggie's way of saying "get off my ass."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's that subtle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eagle's claws and a bear's balls that's what her profile says.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, she's running now, too. These fucking people like to run, don't -- RAY -- Cooch. Woh. Stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron whines backward, and off the road, into some grass Ray steps out, keeping his gaze fixed. Cooch bails from the driver's side, joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Four-hundred feet across a flat area of sandstone and grass clusters, something shimmers in the undulations of the harsh morning sun. Something of pea green and rusty metal... glass catches sunlight and makes prisms. A car. An old res car, sitting in a long, chasm in barely a foot of green water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHORT TIME LATER - PAY Ray and Cooch go through the car, around the car, with gloved hands and grease pencils and plastic bags, sweating in the hot sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excited, Ray walks off, scanning the area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray picks up a handful of stones, sifts them in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch watches him slosh shoes first through a rut where the water shimmers a foot deep or less.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns, shucking up mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray doesn't hear Cooch. He stares past the SAC at the long wide chasm, wet in some places, arid in others, and what he hears must be an echo in his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch is listening to a TRANSMISSION across his radio and he walks off a few feet, exchanging information with the REGIONALS. Ray stands, ankle deep in stagnant water, his face sweat- soaked, his eyes transfixed on heat undulations.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tread matches. It's the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this doesn't make any sense, Ray. If it's just been sitting in this dry wash for seven days... why the hell didn't we find it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because this isn't a dry wash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the Little Walking River.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it was full of water when I drove by here three days ago. Full. I mean... a river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Little Walking River. You're right. This is part of it. So whoever sunk this car didn't compensate for drought. Goddamn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to the water...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A flat-bed tow truck drives past the motel with the killer's car on it. Behind the truck is a fed car which stops at the motel, and the Le Baron which also pulls in. Miles and Sherman get out from the first car, Ray and Cooch bail from the Le Baron. With RADIOS TRANSMITTING, the agents walk, dusty and tired, into room 14. Ray hesitates, snagged by the sight of -- A motorcycle parked in front of the Buffalo Butte Bar. Parked with pick-up trucks and station wagons. It's the mud-caked old Barley. Parked right under the NO INDIANS sign. He puzzles over this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark. Even during the day. Cigarette smoke. Sawdust. On the archaic juke box, RANDY TRAVIS sings "Old 8x10" while behind the bar, the BAR OWNER, an old man with long white hair and beard, busies himself with leather work. SEVERAL WHITE LOCALS sit on the old water drum bar stools. Heads lift, turn when Ray enters in his "fraternizing" clothes -- jeans and boots, leather jacket. He scuffs up thick sawdust as he heads to the furthest booth back where -- Crow Horse sits, alone over a bourbon and a beer. Ray approaches carefully, upset by the sight. He slides into the booth and point blanks the Indian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse shimmers his black eyes onto Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray just looks vacantly at Crow Horse. Crow Horse resents the vacancy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray doesn't blink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse leans toward Ray and speaks more quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is fuming. He can't believe what he's hearing, what's being insinuated, but he's giving it thought and it's getting him angry. He smashes a hand down on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing over the booth is a long, tall RANCHER'S SON. Rangey with red curly hair tucked under a BLACK HILLS CLASSIC cap, and arms built by tractor work. And behind him, TWO OLDER RANCHERS fall in. And ANOTHER YOUNG MAN, grinning with amusement. Ray and Crow Horse look up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray realizes now that they think he's Indian, too. Crow Horse sees this revelation and complicates it by suddenly speaking LAKOTA to Ray. The rancher grabs Ray by the cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray decks him. Backhands him in the solar plexus then, lays a burner of a Quantico roundhouse to his ear, knocking him across the bar, over a mop and bucket and into sawdust. The others start to fall at him but someone has jumped in, holding them back, and sticking himself in the way. It is Brooks. The old timer Ray met his first night here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rancher's son who is coming back with a broken beer bottle, slows his step and shifts his eyes from Brooks to the young fed There is a lot of heavy breathing. But no talking just yet. The young rancher eyes Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray just stands tense, staring at him. And it's strange. Because he hasn't really looked like he has any Indian blood up to this moment. But dressed the way he is, and his eyes glaring, face drawing tense, he might pass for a breed although that's probably the Italian. But Ray doesn't answer the question. Crow Horse starts laughing. Drunkenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse rises and walks unsteadily across the floor, leaving the bar. Brooks is whispering to the others, apparently about who Ray is. The bar man comes up to Ray, holding a tray, on which sits a shot and a beer. Ray looks at it for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray knocks the tray out of his hand, spilling beer and whiskey all over the bar man and the locals around him. And he walks out, leaving the locals confused.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Agent Little Weasel, Federal Bura of your Imagination.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ. You're hammered. What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right about the old man. His power's long dried up. He's supposed to be a medicine man but he won't go see the people. He says we changed, and we don't listen. Well, he don't go out and talk no more. I haven't had a drink in three years but I just turned my sobriety chip into that man behind the bar, and this Hoss is gettin' watered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut the shit. You shouldn't be in here, Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cuz I'm a skin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cuz you're a cop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell me. You tell me who went to the B.I.A. -- Bureau of Indian Annihilation and said I was messin' with your case, man. I don't give a goddamn about your case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I don't give a goddamn about whether you wear a badge or not, Crow Horse, but I didn't cut you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still after Jimmy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They found prints at Blue Legs' place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Jimmy's prints are there. But they cross over Benjamin Black Star's prints. And he wasn't there until six o'clock the mornin' after to get eggs from the chickens. So Jimmy wasn't there til the next day. Follow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, man... you better bust Jimmy and get out before somebody shoots up more than your car next time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next time I'll be ready. You get the word to who ever it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't, Hoss. I don't talk to FBI's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think you was sent here cuz you're a good cop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I was sent here cuz I'm Indian. And a good cop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever think that maybe you was sent here cuz the FBI's need one good reason to take out the entire Warrior Movement. And what better reason than one of their men, gettin' blown away on the res. A low-rent, expendable public servant sent in to take a bullet for his country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sick of your shit -- RANCHER (O.S.) I'm sick of the two of ya timber niggers spewin' off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, we don't speak United States.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well I do. Get the Jesus up, and get the Jesus out or I'm gonna go out to my truck and come back with my hardware.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Woh, hold on there, Jack, you're -- RANCHER'S SON -- don't "jack" me, Squanto. I'll bury your lazy ass right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talkin' to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! No, you butt holes! He ain't skin! He AIN'T SKIN!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah he's In'dn. Miniconjou Sioux.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't Indian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so damn funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's just that the cavalry used to always threaten the Lakota. The cavalry ain't around anymore. The Lakota still are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got no trouble tellin' where you come from, Fat Red.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry. On the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray looks strung-out as he drives. If it's not the conflict at the Butte, it's the dangerous seed Crow Horse planted, and it is playing with his mind. He is on his RADIO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But before he hangs the radio. IT CUTS BACK IN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray seethes quietly as he drives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray keeps driving.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No plates. No registration. Serial numbers removed. And all prints washed off by the river. That's great. This is turning out to be a walk in the park, do you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (woman agent) Come back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray. X22.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I read, Cooch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember that upside down flag back at Jimmy's house? Somebody took it down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They took it down, set fire to it, and threw it on the doorstep of room 13 at the Buffalo Butte Motel. Your room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We traced the number of the truck that dumped it, and it belongs to one Maggie Sanders, also known as Maggie Eagle Bear. She's been all over the res, riling up the traditionals, telling them not to break, and to keep Jimmy in hiding. She's a problem now. And she's yours. Get her off the reservation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Maggie's old pick-up is parked near an arch gate of the tiny cemetery where a tall monument is fenced off from other graves There are tobacco offerings and other medicines hanging on the fence and on the monument. It is a quiet place. Still. Maggie stands before the unkempt monument in her denim jacket, her hair blowing across her face in the wind. She PRAYS IN LAKOTA. Behind her TEN CHILDREN from the Bear Creek School stand, heads bowed respectfully. Two of them sit on the lap of Richard Yellow Bird who looks on from his wheelchair, praying quietly with Maggie. When Maggie completes her prayer, she ties some tobacco to the monument then turns and faces the children. One of them, a LITTLE GIRL -- heavy-set -- raises a hand that we might note is deformed. As many of the children we have seen on the res, are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie smiles at the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CHILDREN LAUGH. All but one boy, who isn't paying attention. He is staring up at a hill, off in the distance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are they all right under here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two-hundred and sixty-seven men, women, old people. And little ones like you. Many killed running along that road you see there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where were they runnin' to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A place called The Stronghold. (a beat) They died for a dream. But you live. You are their great-great grandchildren and you live. We have to honor their dream. Of protecting the Mother Earth. And being proud of being Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mother told me that they call us Indians cuz Columbus was lookin' for India when he discovered our country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, let me tell you something, Henry: just be glad he wasn't looking for Turkey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : on the hill, a figure stands, hands in his pockets, hair blowing in the wind. Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MAGGIE keeping her eyes on the Wasi'cu, but addressing Yellow Bird.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Richard. Sing the Honoring Song with them. I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray stands, watching Maggie walking into the wind, toward him. Behind her an HONORING SONG, sung by ten children haunts the still air. He doesn't budge as she mounts the gentle bluff and joins him there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long silence. The voices carry in the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie looks at him. They lock eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As if exhausted by the thought, Maggie sits down on the bluff, looking out at the children who are still singing the song. As she speaks, she begins digging her fingers in the earth. Ray stands over her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie lifts herself onto her knees and looks down into the small hole she's dug. She picks up a little pine cone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie rises, dusting off her hands. She looks him in the soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray just stares at her, struggling with what he's feeling, what he's hearing. What he's supposed to be feeling. Silence hangs between the two of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie looks at him, considering. Then toward the long dark silhouette of a mountain range across the plains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While she looks off at Paha Sapa, Ray stares at her profile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at Ray with an ironic smile, and she catches him transfixed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie starts giggling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie is laughing as she looks back at the children who are no longer singing. Ray reaches inside his jacket and takes out five polaroids. He shuffles them as he ponders. He hands one to Maggie who has caught herself opening up too much to the Wasi'cu.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie looks at the first photo and says nothing. She hands it back quickly. Ray won't take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie ignores him. Ray studies her reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie is looking away. She picks a long blade of grass and smoothes it in her hands. Ray looks at her a moment longer then rises, dusting off his jeans, and standing there. He thinks for a long moment, pinches the bridge of his nose, then looks out at the Black Hills, pensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maggie watches him go. Looks away. Then watches him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stops. She stands on the bluff, her hair riding the wind and her eyes searing. And then her lips do something that might qualify as half a smile. A sense of humor rising up through anger. Survival humor. Ray looks at her for a long moment. And then he walks on, leaving her there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're praying at the grave. Do you wanna join us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Maggie. But you're gonna have to join me for a ride. I'm taking you to Rapid City.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So much power. I see it in your eyes. This... hunger for power. Or for what you think is power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You burned an American flag today. And left it for me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You desecrated it, it had to be burned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I desecrated it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You forced an innocent man to run like an animal. You've tried to poison my people's hearts against me with your manipulation, with letters I never wrote... you've been watching me eat, work, raise my family... wash myself in the river. And now you're here, arresting me at a sacred place. (a beat) In your eyes, that's power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I plant this tree for you. And I take all this stuff that you've laid on me and my people, and I put it in this hole with this pine cone. (she covers it) And I bury it. Cuz ya know what it is, Ray? Bullshit. And shit is fertilizer. (she stands) And The Mother will turn your lies into something that lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what power is, in the Indian way. (holds her hands out to be cuffed) Take me to Rapid, Ray. I'm the enemy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I told you... that I think Jimmy's innocent... but I'm in over my head... would you believe me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See those Black Hills out there, Ray? When the people lost the land in 1868, the government took everything but those hills. They allowed us to keep those Black Hills, to live there. Signed a treaty. Until they found gold. Then they told us we had to leave because of National interest. They broke that treaty. Anyone who fought or spoke out against it, wound up dead or in jail. And the people wound up here. On a reservation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: While up there, in the Black Hills... they carved the faces of four presidents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your relatives must've taught you something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . (after thought) My father never told anybody he had Indian blood. But he still used a few Indian words around the house. He called me Washee. Said it meant... good boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wa-shee is like... a dumpling. Like tallow we put in stew. I think he was calling you chubby boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever see that car before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's it belong to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help me, Maggie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't see you today, Maggie. (a beat) Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye... Wa-shee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray sits behind the wheel, going through files on his lap, photographs of Indians. And thinking hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks out the window toward the monument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exhausted, Ray lays his head back on the seat, and lets a long, constricted breath free. THUNDER ROLLS like the slow, deep roar of some giant bear up in the hills. He opens his eyes, looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone who fought or spoke out against it... wound up dead or in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself, flustered) That was 1868, Maggie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : rain is coming down, and Maggie is getting the children into the back of her truck. She helps them get a tarp over their heads. Then as Yellow Bird pulls himself into the cab of the truck, she hefts the wheelchair and two boys load it in. She gets in, starts up, and rolls off down the sloping road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray steps out of the car into the rain and closes the door. He stares at the burial grounds. Then slowly, he starts toward them as if magnetically drawn. HEARTBEAT DRUM. A shroud of mist lays over the cemetery, growing thicker as the rain falls harder. DRUM BEATS DEEPER. Ray is walking toward the memorial, getting drenched. Then he hears something strange. HOOFBEATS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : coming down the dirt road, toward him, a HORSEMAN drives his mount at a fast trot. The rider is only a vague image in the mist, his face hidden. As he rides closer, we can make out a shotgun in his hand. And he throws it up, takes aim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RAY paralyzed for a moment. And then going for his gun. But it's not there. He's left it in the car. He breaks into a run. But there's a shorter distance now between the horseman and the car and Ray has no choice but to turn and flee. His boots slap wet pavement, and his breath draws heavy and desperate as he bounds off the road and races down a grassy slope, looking over his shoulder, panicking. His legs and arms churning, his face contorted. And then someone passes him out, running just as hard. AN INDIAN WOMAN in 1890 Winter rags, clutching a BABY to her breast and CRYING. SCREAMING. Ray looks at her, incredulous as he runs. But he keeps running. The rider is right behind him. He FIRES. The GUNSHOT CRACKS the sky like thunder. BOOOOM!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray jumps awake. Cooch is POUNDING on the window. And the three-legged dog inside is BARKING. Ray quickly rolls the window down, letting in THUNDER. Cooch starts to say something then takes note of Ray's peaked face. Sweat runs down his temples, beads at his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Cooch runs to his car. Ray fires the car's big engine and takes off behind Cooch who is driving a fed Chevy. CRAZY HEARTBEAT DRUM INTO -- EXT. GRANDPA REACHES TRATLER - LATE DAY The rain pelts Grandpa's little Airstream trailer, wind snaps at sheet plastic in the windows. An ancient sewing wheel CREAKS RUSTY in the wind. Three clean, late-model fed cars pull down the muddy drive as two SWAT vehicles pull in from another road. The Le Baron pulls in, and Ray bails out with the others. When he sees where he is, he looks distraught. Agents are running behind junked cars, positioning themselves around the trailer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, you alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I... I fell asleep. I can't believe it. I -- COOCH Never turn your radio off! I thought I was gonna find you scalped! Damn it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Cooch. I lost Eagle Bear -- COOCH -- never mind Eagle Bear. We've got Jimmy nailed. Let's go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GRANDPA REACHES TRAILER  LATE DAY The holy man is sitting in his chair, smacking Flies with a swatter. Tonight he wears a black reservation hat and stares vacantly at the TV where RONALD MACDONALD swings a giant baseball bat, and falls on his face, bouncing back up. And then BOOM! The door is open and Cooch leads Miles, Sherman and Ray inside. Cooch has a gun on the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man slowly removes his hat and hangs it on a knee. Carefully he places his wrinkled hands on his thinning white hair. His eyes seek out Ray who stands in the doorway, M-16 in hand, looking concerned. He stares at Ray. Cooch storms into a back bedroom, Miles moves to a window. Sherman stands over the old man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa looks at Sherman, ignores him, looks back at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With RADIO TRANSMISSIONS crackling through the house, Cooch comes back down the hall, and heads to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray starts to follow but he sees Sherman pick something up from near Grandpa. The 500 year-old turtleshell rattle. Grandpa's eyes widen slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sherman drops the turtleshell rattle on the linoleum floor. Then drives his heel into it, CRUSHING the fragile turtleshell. Ray grabs him and slams him into the tin wall. Miles gets between them, grabbing Sherman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're out the door, leaving the old man to sit looking down at the shattered rattle. He closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where is he, Sam? Where's Jimmy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a medicine man, Ray. The "spiritual leader" of the Warriors. That right, Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trailer's clean, let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You been the one making it rain like that, out there, Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, put that down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you make Jimmy outrun an M-16, Sam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sherman!
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: COME ON GUYS, COME ON, GUYS

dialogue.raw_text: ! HEY! -- RADIO HE'S ON THE ROOF! HE'S ON THE FUCKING ROOF! COME ON GUYS, COME ON, GUYS!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a blizzard of rain, Jimmy Looks Twice in a cowboy shirt, jeans and boots, leaps off the top of the Airstream, clutching his medicine bundle. FLOODLIGHTS HIT him from all directions. BULLHORNS screaming at him. He tries to turn a corner and runs right into a fed. Ray, having run out the back door has slammed right into him. He has his rifle on him, and they stare each other down for a split second before he is converged on. Guns at his back, at his head. He is swept off his feet, face down, and frisked. He looks up at Ray, desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another fed, pushes his face into the mud, cuffs him behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With two FIVE MAN SWAT TEAMS swarming the area, and six agents pushing Jimmy toward a car, Cooch stands there in the pouring rain, looking relieved. Ray stands near him, looking abhorred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray watches Jimmy as he is shoved into the back of Miles and Sherman's car and driven away. He is twisting around in his seat to look at Ray. Desperately. The SWAT teams disband, return to their vehicles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch heads to his car and Ray starts shuffling toward his as if he is dared by it all. He is looking at the trailer and there on the rickety porch is Grandpa. He comes down the steps slowly, holding his hat on against the wind. He watches the cars pulling out. Ray walks over to him, looking sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And after a moment of locking gazes, he starts for his car,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray frowns, disturbed by this story. The old man is speaking with conviction. With power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stands, almost paralyzed, digesting this. He turns and looks into the old man's sharp eyes. Grandpa has closed his eyes, and as he is pulverized by the rain, he turns his face toward it and from way down in his belly, he begins to SING IN LAKOTA. And it is too much. Too weird. He wheels and hurries to the car. Gets in, and beats a fast path out of the old man's lonesome patch of land.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brother, the old man told me about you. Listen to me: what was Leo trying to tell me? He wanted to meet me at Maisy --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Save your speeches for prison, Jimmy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn. That's one hard running Indian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's over, Ray. I aged five years. But it's over. At least I'm gonna look like I'm ready for the advisory desk. Let's go get a beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look... I'm not who you think I am. (a long beat) I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out back that way... is a placed called Wounded Knee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was one years old there when our people were shot down. My mother hid me in the snow in a blanket. One of those killed was a Holy Man called Wakiyan Cante -- Thunder Heart. They killed him while he was running for The Stronghold. It is his blood -- the same blood that spilled on the grass and snow at Wounded Knee -- that runs through your heart like a buffalo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thunder Heart has come. Sent here to a troubled place to help his people. That's what I am told. Maybe you're right and I am mistaken. Your mind is young, mine is old. If so, so be it. Ho Hecetu Yelo. I'll speak no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: knifes the sky. THUNDER ROLLS, and rumbles into POOL BALLS -- EXT. BUFFALO BUTTE MOTEL AND BAR - LATE DAY The agents have taken over both sides of the streets, gathered in front of the bar and the motel, putting firearms into cases, removing flak jackets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: knock from inside the bar while outside, A DAKOTAN takes a piss near a truck while his GIRLFRIEND stands at his back, yelling at him. CHARLIE DANIELS sings country on the juke Ray heads to room 13, starts unlocking the door. Cooch comes up behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch throws a mock punch at Ray and he mock blocks, tired. He musters a smile. But he isn't all there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods. Cooch lets a few agents walk past, LAUGHING. He speaks quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray tries to break a smile again. Cooch cups his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch stares at Ray. The younger agent looks like he indeed has a fever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch hurries across the rain-swept street. Ray steps inside and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Buffalo burgers and cold beer, Raymond. Don't worry about the sign out front... you don't have to be Indian anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a fever. You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen: when we get back tomorrow, you're gonna find Tully laying a promotion on you. S.A.C. He wants to prove that his yuppie agents are making good. He's offering you New York. Tell him you want Atlanta.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cuz I want New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cooch. They sent us out here because the place was being neglected. Now, all of a sudden, there's two five man SWAT teams out there tonight. Bell Huey choppers flying all over the place. Federal occupation to catch one guy. Why, Cooch? What's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: National security, Ray. Get some sleep. Tomorrow, we fly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray closes the door, and stands there. He seems to be having trouble breathing. He looks down at his boots. There is something on the floor. Something that has been slipped under the door earlier. He just stares down at it. Then slowly stoops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: the polaroid of the res car he gave to Maggie earlier. She has returned it. He turns it over. Written across the white backing of the photo, in dark black marker is the name -- YELLOW BIRD. Ray stares at this for a moment then hurries over to boxes of files on the bed. He rummages like a nervous thief and comes up with a folder. He flips through it, casting off files and 302's and profiles and finally stopping on -- The 8x10 BLACK AND WHITE of Richard Yellow Bird seen earlier. Sitting in his wheelchair, Red Power cap on, tattoos marring big arms. And under it a DOUBLE MUG SHOT stamped LEAVENWORTH PRISON. Under that ANOTHER PRISON MUG SHOT stamped SIOUX FALLS PRISON. And under that a -- THIRD MUG SHOT stamped "PAROLED." Ray, his eyes fixed on this one, takes a few steps and sits on the end of the bed. He then stuffs the file back in a box, and takes off toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron throws up loose rock and red dust, driving toward a place where the sun begins a slow drop behind the Black Hills. HORSES run out of the road. HEARTBEAT DRUM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tarpaper shack. Outhouse. Clothesline on which jerked meat hangs. No cars. A lonely, unnerving place. Le Baron pulls in. Ray gets out, adjusting the gun at the back of his waistband. He starts for the shack. Ray raps a fist on the splintered plywood door. Knocks again. He checks out a boarded- up window. The door finally opens. Just a crack. Tiny black eyes peer out into the fading light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sticks his open badge, gold eagle wings, near the crack. The door closes. Then unlatches and opens. Yellow Bird sits there in his wheelchair, tiny tobacco bundles in his lap. He's been tying them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pivots his chair to allow Ray room to enter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm looking for Richard Yellow Bird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Washington Redskin. Thought you'd be gone by now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird, in a T-shirt that reveals twenty different ink tattoos, rolls himself across the warped floorboards to a cheese crate where his eye glasses sit. He puts the thick bifocals on and focuses resentfully on Ray in the ochre flicker of the dirty room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray walks across the room, his eyes on a covert mission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird stares at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird looks at Ray, strangely, shaking his head. Ray starts to look like maybe the game's not working. Like maybe this doesn't add up. But -- YELLOW BIRD I'm here, ain't I? Ray lets a tense breath out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sits in a busted chair, reaches down to his ankle holster and pulls out a .38. He holds it, resting it on the arm of the chair. He strains to look out through the boarded window. Yellow Bird fidgets in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird stands. He takes a step forward. Limping. He's got leg problems but he can walk. Heels first. And bowed. But he can walk. He is shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird wheels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is trying hard not to reveal his horror at this confession, at this understanding of the machinery. He sits there with his gun, blinking away sweat that beads at his brow. Yellow Bird is weeping in a highpitched voice that doesn't match his great bulk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray grabs onto these words, rolls them silently on his lips And now Yellow Bird is getting suspicious of the fed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray snaps out his gun, straight-armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird jumps back, raising his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then HEADLIGHTS pierce the gaps in the boarded windows. Yellow Bird collapses against the wall, bangs his head off it. He lets a long, pained, cry escape from under his breath and he begins a slow slide down the wall, to the floor. Ray peers out the cracks in the boards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gets up, putting his gun away and heading to the door. He stops and looks back at the Indian, sitting on the floor, clutching his knees, staring into the kerosene flicker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yellow Bird looks at him, his glasses foggy, his face contorted And Ray leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What ya want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must be a bitch getting around in that wheelchair. How long you been in it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since I got a iron pipe put across my knees, man. Fight with three wasi'cus, ya know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At Sioux Falls Pen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, that was Leavenworth. This -- (shows a scar) was Sioux Falls. What ya want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leavenworth a tough joint?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever try solitary confinement?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Can't say that I have, Richard. Richard do you know why I'm here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Washington sent ya. I know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Washington sent me, Richard. They sent me here because this whole thing has been fucked. Do you know what I mean when I say this whole thing has been fucked, Richard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An arrangement was made between you... and us. Do you remember that arrangement?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not for long, Richard. You got early parole under the stipulation that you would help us in a situation, and you didn't deliver.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck you talkin' about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get up out of the chair, Richard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's with you people? Why do ya have to fuck with my head all the time? I came through, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get up out of the chair, and walk toward the backdoor, Richard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not moving) I get thrown in solitary until I don't know my own fuckin' name, and then you people tell me I can beat nine years if I help you. I helped you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They said I'd never see FBI again, and I'm livin' with you fuckers. I don't feed ya information on the Warriors, it's back to the pen. I don't do this, back to the pen. Your word against my word. Against a con Indian's word. I really got a chance, man, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They sent me here, Richard because they said you didn't hold up your end of the arrangement, and I have to transport you back to Leavenworth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying) What the fuck, man? What do you people want? I did what you wasi'cu's told me to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo Fast Elk... is alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No way. No fuckin' way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How the hell do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I blew his back out with a buffalo gun, that's how I know! Now you're gonna say I didn't, so you can throw me back in solitary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The men who came to see you at Leavenworth. The one's who made the arrangement... who were they? Maybe I can talk to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miles. Three other suits. That's all I know 'em as -- suits. Were you there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You turned Leo over on his face. But the coyotes must've turned him back over, man, cuz his spirit is out. It's out, and it knows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about spirits? You ain't no In'dn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leo knew something heavy and was trying to tell Jimmy. But you must not know how serious it was or you would have delivered. Do you realize what Leo could have told Jimmy?! Do you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took him out before he got the chance. He didn't say nothin' about Tashka Sha. And now his spirit is in the dirt. Forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's Tashka Sha, speak English, speak English!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Red Deer Table! What's with you, man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute. Wait -- what are you doin'? You ain't a FBI. You ain't the law. Let me see your --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the fucking law!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep talking, Yellow Bird...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I know... is I did what I did... and I ain't in solitary, gettin' pumped up with downer, gettin' beat to shit. But I tell you what, Suit. Take me back. Cuz I can't take this shit no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man, I don't know who the fuck I am no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and me both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray steps out into the falling night. There is a car parked there. With a high aerial. Ray raises a hand in a slight wave, walks on. At the fed car, A REGIONAL AGENT behind the wheel, waves a hand. Watches Ray get into the Le Baron. Ray gets in the car and takes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TRAVELING Ray drives like a crazy man through the dark reservation. Through miles of open land and strange rock formations. And he looks trapped. HEADLIGHTS flicker in his rearview. He sees this. Slams the gas pedal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron races at 85 down the dirt stretch. A moment later a car rattles by at 90.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray reaches over to the passenger seat and pulls up the M- 16. He lays it across his lap. Looks in the rearview again. Then makes a sudden sharp turn. He pulls off the road quickly, throwing up dust into the already foggy night, the car goes out of control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car that was following drives right past the narrow layby, hidden by grassy slopes and keeps flying down the long stretch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray skids through the dirt, trying to stop -- he can't -- and the Le Baron fishtails, smashing into a chain-link fence. And coming to a stop. Breathing as if he's been running not driving, Ray looks behind him to make sure he lost the car. He did. When he turns back to his wheel, he sees -- THROUGH THE CHAINLINK FENCE lit by his headlights: THE WOUNDED KNEE gravesite. He is right up on the arch, and the tall stone marker beyond it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron just sits parked, headlights making the night fog crawl up from the base of the old tomb, along the fence. The driver's door opens slowly. And Ray steps out. He walks through the arch. Into the small fenced area. Up to the stone which is overgrown with stubborn weeds, half-hidden in mist. Ray studies the tomb.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE NAMES ON THE STONE ARE CHISELED VERTICALLY

direction.raw_text: : THE NAMES ON THE STONE ARE CHISELED VERTICALLY:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HIGH HAWK AFRAID OF BEAR Weeds are grown up over the rest of the names. Ray's hands clear them, grab at them and rip them away from more names:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With frantic abandon, Ray is ripping weeds away. He drops to his knees, clearing weeds.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PRETTY HAWK BLUE AMERICAN SHERMAN HORN CLOUD

direction.raw_text: DOWN and then suddenly back up to the name:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RAY kneeling in the weeds, the wind getting restless around him, screaming the way plains winds do but only these winds are filled with a whistling. What sounds like EAGLE BONE WHISTLES, piping shrill. Ray kneels before the marker, staring at the name on the stone, his hair thrown around by the wind that drives across the grass, whistling eagles, building to an unbearable, pitch. Ray stares at the name as if he is looking through a small hole into another world. A world that frightens him. He gets up and backs away from the stone, through the gate. And gets back in his car, quickly. He takes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little home on the river. Dark. Empty. Ray runs up the steps, pounds at the door. No answer. Pounds again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He keeps knocking. Nothing. He hurries back down the steps, starts around the back of the house and something attacks him, leaps at him from the dark, knocking him off his feet, into the grass. Hits him again. But as quickly as he falls, he rolls, throwing up his hands and blocking a savage kick aimed for his face. He traps the boot, twists it and drops the attacker onto his back. In a matter of seconds, he is on top of the man, sticking his gun in his throat. He grabs a flashlight from his jacket and shines it in the man's face. Crow Horse. Breathing like a wild animal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse lies there, breathing heavy. Ray on top of him, still clutching his gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The land behind Red Deer Table is Badlands. Badlands pierced by a few rutted old wagon roads. At a place between two grotesque buttes, Crow Horse stops, looking uneasy. He digs into his pocket, pulls out some loose tobacco and spills it on the ground. Then he walks on. Ray observes this, starting forward, then stopping long enough to fish a cigarette out from his pocket and drop it next to Crow Horse's offering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Crow Horse walk, carefully under a full moon, scanning the area. Crow Horse stops, checks out some tracks. Ray walks on, looking up at the table. He shines his flashlight up and it illuminates -- A RED RIBBON, tied on stakes on a ridge. Ten stakes. Twenty stakes. Ribbons blowing in the wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sweeps the light along, walking faster, and then something frightening occurs. Something... some unseen thing snags him by the leg, sucking him into the Earth with a horrible GUSHING SOUND. Ray is drawn into a hole up to his hips, a bluish-black slime, oozing out around him. Crow Horse grabs him, struggling to pull him up. He does, stumbling back and stepping into a hole himself. The two men are wheeling, throwing flashlight beams around, slapping through a wet jelly, and finally getting their bearings. Ray touches the ground where a blue-black chemical solution oozes out with water from the aquifer below. His flashlight scans -- TWENTY DRILLED HOLES IN THE EARTH. A uranium strip-mining grid laid out in a 50 x 60 pattern. The far side is fenced by flagged stakes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray goes to another hole and sticks his arm in up to the elbow, sniffs the solution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is looking past Crow Horse at -- Something strange in the moonlight. COYOTES. Some forty yards away, on a flat stretch of stoney ground. Six Coyotes, dancing in the shadows of rock formations. MOVING IN ON THEM as Ray walks forward, they circle... scatter... run back... circle again. Look straight at Ray, eyes glowing. And run.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: -- TWENTY DRILLED HOLES IN THE EARTH

dialogue.raw_text: Uranium. Test holes. Somebody came in from the Nebraska side, and did some shotgun testin'. They're gettin' ready to suck this baby dry.

dialogue.raw_text: ... CROW HORSE What?

dialogue.raw_text: That's what we're doing here. National interest. National security. Only this time it's not gold. It's uranium.

dialogue.raw_text: Leo knew about it. Tried to tell Jimmy, get the Warriors involved.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So they took care of Leo.

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to the water... the river keeps goin' down then rising again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're drainin' our water table. That's our life, man...

direction.raw_text: - RAY and Crow Horse walk toward them. To the place they just left. A place in the dirt, they were digging up. When they reach it, they stare down into the dirt.

direction.raw_text: lies there, face down. Denim jacket and a shock of black hair, thrown into tangles and dirt. It was buried. Until the coyote caught wind. Crow Horse bends down, touches the jacket... turns the body over And almost vomits when he sees Maggie Eagle Bear.

direction.raw_text: looks down in disbelief.

direction.raw_text: in the moonlight. And RAY'S YELLING ECHOING up out of the rocks

direction.raw_text: hollow as the Crow Horse motorcycle chutters down and coasts up in front of one of the little homes -- rundown but it has a satellite dish and a decent car like so many. The Le Baron pulls up behind it.

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse walks over to Ray's window, his jeans and boots muddy. No one speaks for a long moment, the night filled by crickets. And that one dog.

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse crosses the street. Ray sits there, and he looks almost hurt by this statement. But he is the white man. But he is Indian. He lets a long breath escape, rubs at a temple. He takes out a smoke. Tries to light it. His hands are shaking too badly. But he gets it lit, and sits tense, looking in his rearview.

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. It's time to beat the drum. You better wait here. He don't trust the white man.

direction.raw_text: Oliver Clear Moon sits in a chair, his strong Indian mouth, beginning to tighten at the jowls. Across from him, Crow Horse sits on the edge of a couch. MRS. CLEAR MOON, a rotund, gentle woman brings him a coffee. A TEENAGE GIRL in a men's extra-large T-shirt stands in the hall, looking at him. Clear Moon in pajamas, rises, and with a coffee in hand, starts walking in slow steps toward the kitchen. He loses control before he gets there and hurls the cup across the room into the sink, smashing it. He wheels and faces Crow Horse. He SPEAKS LAKOTA. Asking questions. Crow Horse SPEAKS LAKOTA. Answering him. Mrs. Clear Moon, understanding, shakes her head in disbelief and her eyes begin to well. Oliver, walking back to his chair, sits, and thinks for a moment. MORE LAKOTA. He gets up, goes to a drawer and rummages. He sits again, and tosses something onto the coffee table. It is a badge. A tribal police badge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nervously awaits Crow Horse's words as he appears at the window again. The Indian shows hope in his tired eyes.

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse looks at Ray who stares dead ahead.

dialogue.raw_text: Alright. Shit's comin' down. He's callin' council fire. All the old chiefs and the warriors, too. I gotta be at Grandpa's place in two hours. We need to get the tribe together. We need to block this thing.

dialogue.raw_text: What we need... is Richard Yellow Bird.

direction.raw_text: Ray steps away from the door, looking around the vast plains as the sun comes up out of the Black Hills. He is roadblocked, and it shows in his eyes. It's all getting too big. Crow Horse leans against the shack, watching Ray. And then RADIO STATIC from inside the Le Baron. Ray pivots and stares at it as if someone is inside the car. His call signal is being paged. But he just stands there, looking at it.

direction.raw_text: Ray reaches inside the car and lifts the handset. He takes a breath before pressing it to his lips.

direction.raw_text: Ray has cast off his field clothes and is halfway into one of his cleaner suits. He looks haggard but still buoyant, his eyes piercing. The connecting door creaks open and Cooch walks in. The SAC is freshly showered and he is fidgeting with a Windsor knot. He studies his number two man, says nothing for a moment but is obviously holding something down. His face is a red hue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at Cooch. When he speaks, his voice is dry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch crosses the room, and picks up Ray's jeans which look like they went through a sandlot tackle match in a mud hole. Ray tucks his clean shirt in; watching Cooch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch walks up to Ray slowly and takes his face in his hand, turning it toward lamp light to study the bruise along his left eye, a residual from a Crow Horse hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods, and Cooch slowly breaks a smile. An insecure smile but a smile just the same. He starts to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch laughs in amusement and Ray's face crinkles into a grin as he lowers his eyes, wiping a paper towel over his face. And then, suddenly, Ray lunges at Cooch. He slams the Agent in Charge against the hollow wall, and holds him there. His eyes wild.

direction.raw_text: Cooch is stunned.

direction.raw_text: Cooch's eyes go frighteningly cold. He can't believe what he's hearing.

direction.raw_text: Ray says nothing. He just stands there, against the sink, breathing like a fighter against the turnbuckle.

You don't question that, you don't go digging into that shit -- that's insubordination. Jesus Christ -- RAY -- if they mine uranium there, these people will have no place left to go...

dialogue.raw_text: We were sworn in on the Constitution to protect federal matters, Ray. I don't know about uranium, I don't know about Red Dog Table -- all I know is we did our job. It's over.

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Ray. You think I don't like the Indians? Not true. These were noble people but their day is gone. They're a conquered nation. They want all of America back but they can't even keep the garbage out of their own front yards. It's sad, Ray. But it's just the way it is. We have to function as a colonial police force out here.

Cooch walks with Ray toward the Le Baron, looking at him as the go. Ray looks better as he breathes the morning air. As they pass the second fed car, the back window power glides down, and someone looks out with a friendly smile.

direction.raw_text: Ray stops dead. Beholds the Tribal President who wears a western cut jacket and a strained expression behind his smile. He hole a hand out to Ray.

direction.raw_text: Ray stares at him, speechless. Horrified. What is he doing here? What about the council fire? Ray somehow nods. Then walks on to the Le Baron. Cooch gets behind the wheel of the car that Clear Moon sits in. Clear Moon's eyes follow Ray to the car.

dialogue.raw_text: You got the troublemakers off our land. Good, Was-te.

dialogue.raw_text: (Ray) How the hell do you know? (Yellow Bird) I blew his back out with a buffalo gun, that's how I know. And now you're gonna say I didn't and put me back in solitary?!

direction.raw_text: just ahead, the earth is gone. A wavering heat pond turns out to be a crevice and they nose down into it, burying the front end in sand and rock. WINDSHIELD SHATTERS.

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. The Stronghold. Get us in there, we got a chance.

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron is stuck, wheels spinning out. Ray and Cooch bail. Guns drawn, they start running for the Stronghold.

direction.raw_text: the caravan slides in recklessly, two of the fed cars coming dangerously close to going over the edge. The regional officers and six Clear Moon goons empty out, running down the dip, rifles and shotguns ready. Three more field agents come down from another direction, followed by Cooch. Sherman hands a bullhorn to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of FIFTEEN PRIMING FIREARMS stops Ray and Crow Horse in their tracks. Just twenty feet from The Stronghold. Crow Horse, windless, stumbles to a knee. Ray turns slowly, facing the small army.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse, rises, sucking wind, and ditches his gun in the Badlands. Ray holds onto his .45 a moment longer. Then drops it. He stares at -- THE WALL OF MEN Cooch, SA Miles, SA Sherman, Six regional officers, six Clear Moon goons. And now, coming out of the backseat of Cooch's Chevy, Oliver Clear Moon, walking tentatively, cautiously. Cooch lowers the bullhorn. He takes the opportunity to stare at Ray. To let Ray stare at him. The older agent looks broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cooch walks toward him, a gun hanging at one side, bullhorn at the other. The agents behind him, around him, all raise rifles, all take aim. Sherman, looking sick, gets to a knee and sets aim. The sound of clacking steel, all around. But Cooch seems disturbed by the sound. Because its coming from above. He raises an eye from the rifle sight to see -- ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE FIFTEEN INDIANS, training rifles and shotguns down below.

dialogue.raw_text: Ray. I'm coming to talk to you. I'm gonna walk you out of here. And we're gonna get the hell outta this place.

direction.raw_text: looks up from his rifle, bewildered. Then alarmed.

direction.raw_text: We PAN across fifteen Indians -- old people, women, kids. Their weapons are weak but many. And at the end of the row, Maisy Blue Legs rises, clutching a rifle. And PAST HER, ANOTHER. TRADITIONAL PEOPLE, many from the trading post porch, rise to the edge, armed. Silent. Twenty, twenty-five, thirty traditionals, forming a line along the ridge, a line that runs in a circle, broken by the Stronghold entrance, then starting again on the next butte. Thirty-five, forty of them. And more, standing along the opposite craggy rock, some wearing tractor caps, some cowboy hats, some just long hair blowing in the wind. Fifty, sixty, SEVENTY-FIVE RESERVATION PEOPLE forming a circle on the rocks; it's Little Big Horn revisited. A fourteen year-old boy struggles to keep a huge shotgun at his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE

direction.raw_text: stands equally astonished, assessing the back-up.

direction.raw_text: stepping stiffly but steadily through the line of armed locals, pushing his way to the very edge so as to look down, Grandpa Sam Reaches. The wind makes feathery tails out of his long thinning strips of white hair.

direction.raw_text: Cooch slowly, lets the bullhorn fall. Then the rifle. He looks back at Sherman who does the same, and all the way down the line, everyone dropping their arms under the threat of a lot more guns from above. And now Ray walks forward, collecting his gun. Anderson Chasing Hawk, one of the Warriors, runs down to Ray, breathless.

direction.raw_text: Ray notices that Cooch is staring at him, hard. He shakes his head slowly. Strongly.

direction.raw_text: into and through the fast-moving clouds that the Lakota call The Grandfathers as the HEARTBEAT DRUM and LAKOTA SINGERS takes over all sound.

direction.raw_text: The HIGH WINDS of THREE MEDIA HELICOPTERS are delighting a storm of Indian children and BARKING DOGS, running through the streets past junked cars on blocks. Over on a little plot of grass and dirt, a pair of hands are digging a small hole. Ray lays a pine cone in the hole and looks down at it for a moment... before hand-plowing the dirt back over it and patting it flat. He rises, knocking dirt off his knees and hands. Crow Horse walks over, bandaged and favoring wounds, and Ray falls in with him, walking down the middle of the village road. His eyes are tired. But hopeful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray nods, encouraged as they walk along. His eyes follow the helicopters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They reach the dusty, dented Le Baron and stand there, looking at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crow Horse offers a hand to Ray. He takes it in a white man's shake then follows Walter's cue into the Indian "allies" grip and slap. They hold it there, looking into each other's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray ponders for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray shrugs. Crow Horse discreetly gestures below his belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray cracks a smile, a long time coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stands looking at him, searching for words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray goes to get in his car. But he sees someone sitting across the street on the trading post porch. The old man. Ray considers him for a moment then walks over. They lock eyes. Grandpa stares at Ray as if he's never seen him before, and then arcs a brow. He touches his sleeve at the wrist. Ray rolls his sleeve back to reveal his Rolex. Grandpa smiles and Ray strips it off. He hands it to the old man and his face crinkles into caliche earth. Grandpa holds the watch up in the light, admires it then puts it in his shirt pocket. He moves a flat hand through the air in the "done deal" sign language. Ray, a little surprised that he gets nothing in the trade, returns the smile and walks away. He gets to his car and wipes away two inches of dust from the broken windshield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After THREE TRIES, he gets the engine started. He pulls his gun off his waistband, goes to lay it on the passenger seat and finds something there. Grandpa's sacred caanunpa. The Pipe. Symbol of truth. Ray looks out the window at the old man who is watching him with those sharp black eyes. Ray lifts his hand, holds it flat, and does the Sioux done deal sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Le Baron eats up the dirt road at a moderate, gravel crunching pace. It slows as it passes Maggie Eagle Bear's quiet home on the river. Children walk with the old woman, carrying buckets from the river. The Le Baron slows to a crawl, then drives on.

direction.raw_text: driving off the res, under big sky as it ascends a rough hill, waddles through potholes, negotiates with some horses in the road and rolls on toward the reservation line where the sun throws shadows that look like an old man dancing.

direction.raw_text: where West goes to Rapid City, and East back to Bear Creek, Ray stops like the bullet-punched sign orders. He doesn't go West. Doesn't go East. He sits there. Fishes a smoke out from a pocket, clicks a lighter, and fires up. He sits there, smoking. Deliberating.
direction.name: direction
